Chicopee, Mass. - NARA - 523488.jpg|thumb|A bobbin boy in 1911]] A '''bobbin boy''' was a boy who worked in a [[textile mill]] in the 18th and early 19th centuries. He would bring [[bobbin]]s to the women at the looms when they called for them, and collected the full bobbins of spun [[cotton]] or [[wool]] thread. They also would be expected to fix minor problems with the [[machines]]. Average [[Salary|pay]] was about $1.00 a week, with days often beginning at 5:30 am and ending around 7:30 pm six days a week. One example of rising from this job to great heights in America was young Andrew Carnegie, who at age 13 worked as a bobbin boy in 1848.<ref name="Carnegie">[http://books.google.com/books?id=RekoAAAAYAAJ&printsec=titlepage&dq=Carnegie+knows+the+presid... Autobiography of Andrew Carnegie] p. 34</ref> ==Notable bobbin boys== The following persons once worked as a bobbin boy: * [[Andrew Carnegie]], the great steel tycoon<ref name="Carnegie" /> * [[Nathaniel Prentice Banks]], [[Governor of Massachusetts]] and [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] general * [[Robert Frost]], Poet ==Notes== <ref>{{cite web|title=Industry Comes of Age|url=http://apushripon.webs.com/american_pageant/Chapter%2024.pdf|publisher=American Pageant|accessdate=17 January 2012}}</ref> {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bobbin boy}} [[Category:Industrial occupations]] [[Category:Child labor in the United States]] [[Category:Obsolete occupations]] [[Category:Textile industry]] {{Job-stub}}
